title.value: Mortality trends and length of stays among hospitalized patients with COVID-19 in Ontario and Québec (Canada): a population-based cohort study of the first three epidemic waves
title.justification: This title directly reflects the paper's focus on analyzing mortality trends and hospital stays among COVID-19 patients in specific regions of Canada.
title.quote: Mortality trends and length of stays among hospitalized patients with COVID-19 in Ontario and Québec (Canada): a population-based cohort study of the first three epidemic waves

extractions.description: The paper examines the mortality trends and hospital length of stay for COVID-19 patients in Ontario and Québec, during the first three epidemic waves using population-based hospitalization data. It explores the changes in in-hospital mortality and ICU stay duration, accounting for patient and hospital level factors, in order to understand how these variables evolved through the pandemic's waves.

type.justification: The study involves analyzing real-world data from hospitalizations, focusing on statistical analysis to derive insights about trends and outcomes.
type.quote: We conducted a retrospective population-based cohort study using provincial COVID-19 hospitalization databases from Ontario and Québec.

name.justification: The paper studies the patterns and determinants of health and disease conditions, specifically COVID-19 outcomes, in defined populations.
name.quote: Background: Epidemics of COVID-19 strained hospital resources. We describe temporal trends in mortality risk and length of stays in hospital and intensive care units (ICUs) among patients with COVID-19 hospitalized through the first three epidemic waves in Canada.

name.justification: The focus is on COVID-19, which is an infectious disease, while analyzing the impact on hospital systems and patient outcomes.
name.quote: Keywords: COVID-19 hospitalization mortality risk length of stay in intensive care units

name.justification: The paper evaluates the impact of the COVID-19 epidemic on health care system operations, such as hospital capacity and mortality trends.
name.quote: Conclusions: In-hospital mortality risks and length of ICU stays declined over time despite changing patient demographics. Continuous population-based monitoring of patient outcomes in an evolving epidemic is necessary for health system preparedness and response.

name.justification: This dataset was used to obtain hospitalization data for Ontario, contributing to the empirical analysis of the study.
name.quote: Hospitalization data for Ontario was obtained from the Ontario’s Case and Contact Management (CCM+)

referenced_paper_title.justification: The document does not mention a specific paper title referring to this dataset.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Hospitalization data for Ontario was obtained from the Ontario’s Case and Contact Management (CCM+)

name.value: Maintenance et exploitation des données pour l’étude de la clientèle hospitalière database (MED-ÉCHO live)
name.justification: This dataset was used for obtaining hospitalization data in Québec, essential for the study's analysis.
name.quote: In Québec, data were obtained from the Maintenance et exploitation des données pour l’étude de la clientèle hospitalière database (MED-ÉCHO live).

referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper does not specify a referenced paper for this dataset.
referenced_paper_title.quote: In Québec, data were obtained from the Maintenance et exploitation des données pour l’étude de la clientèle hospitalière database (MED-ÉCHO live).
